title: First $10,000 Of Wages Per Year Taken Into Account
text: Editor's Note:Pub. L. 109-432, Sec. 105(e)(4)(A), repealed Sec. 51A, effective for individuals who begin work for the employer after December 31, 2006.The amount of the qualified first-year wages, and the amount of qualified second-year wages, which may be taken into account with respect to any individual shall not exceed $10,000 per year.

title: Amounts Treated As Wages
text: Editor's Note:Pub. L. 109-432, Sec. 105(e)(4)(A), repealed Sec. 51A, effective for individuals who begin work for the employer after December 31, 2006.The term “wages” includes amounts paid or incurred by the employer which are excludable from such recipient's gross income under--—section105(relating to amounts received under accident and health plans),—section106(relating to contributions by employer to accident and health plans),—section127(relating to educational assistance programs), but only to the extent paid or incurred to a person not related to the employer, or—section129(relating to dependent care assistance programs).The amount treated as wages by clause(i)or(ii)for any period shall be based on the reasonable cost of coverage for the period, but shall not exceed the applicable premium for the period under section4980B(f)(4).

title: Rules For Agricultural And Railway Labor
text: Editor's Note:Pub. L. 109-432, Sec. 105(e)(4)(A), repealed Sec. 51A, effective for individuals who begin work for the employer after December 31, 2006.If such recipient is an employee to whom subparagraph(A)or(B)of section51(h)(1)applies, rules similar to the rules of such subparagraphs shall apply except that——such subparagraph(A)shall be applied by substituting “$10,000” for “$6,000”, and—such subparagraph(B)shall be applied by substituting “$833.33” for “$500”.

                                 31, 2006.If such recipient is an employee to whom subparagraph(A)or(B)of section51(h)(1)applies, rules similar to the rules of such  subparagraphs shall apply except that—I.R.C. § 51A(b)(5)(C)(i)—such  subparagraph(A)shall be applied by substituting “$10,000” for “$6,000”,  andI.R.C. § 51A(b)(5)(C)(ii)—such subparagraph(B)shall be applied by substituting “$833.33” for “$500”.

title: General
text: Editor's Note:Pub. L. 109-432, Sec. 105(e)(4)(A), repealed Sec. 51A, effective for individuals who begin work for the employer after December 31, 2006.The term “long-term family assistance recipient” means any individual who is certified by the designated local agency (as defined in section51(d)(11))——as being a member of a family receiving assistance under a IV-A program (as defined in section51(d)(2)(B)) for at least the 18-month period ending on the hiring date,—(i) as being a member of a family receiving such assistance for 18 months beginning after the date of the enactment of this section, and—as having a hiring date which is not more than 2 years after the end of the earliest such 18-month period, or—(i) as being a member of a family which ceased to be eligible after the date of the enactment of this section for such assistance by reason of any limitation imposed by Federal or State law on the maximum period such assistance is payable to a family, and—as having a hiring date which is not more than 2 years after the date of such cessation.

logical_structure.result: Editor's Note:Pub. L. 109-432, Sec. 105(e)(4)(A), repealed Sec. 51A, effective for individuals who begin work for the employer after December 31, 2006.The term “long-term family assistance recipient” means any individual who is certified by the designated local agency (as defined in section51(d)(11))——as being a member of a family receiving assistance under a IV-A program (as defined in section51(d)(2)(B)) for at least the 18-month period ending on the hiring date,—(i) as being a member of a family receiving such assistance for 18 months beginning after the date of the enactment of this section, and—as having a hiring date which is not more than 2 years after the end of the earliest such 18-month period, or—(i) as being a member of a family which ceased to be eligible after the date of the enactment of this section for such assistance by reason of any limitation imposed by Federal or State law on the maximum period such assistance is payable to a family, and—as having a hiring date which is not more than 2 years after the date of such cessation.
